docs.lead_paragraph: People living below the poverty line are more likely to have very high levels of C-reactive protein, a marker of inflammation that increases the risk for heart disease and death, a new study has found. C-reactive protein is produced in response to injury or infection, but some people have chronically high levels of it. The study, published in the September issue of Brain, Behavior and Immunity, found no significant difference by socioeconomic status in those with moderate or high levels of C-reactive protein, but there was a significant difference in very high levels.

headline.main: A Link Between Poverty and a Telltale Protein

docs.abstract: Dr Dawn E Alley leads study while at University of Southern California that shows that people living in poverty are at higher risk of having seriously elevated levels of C-Reactive protein, which is marker for heart disease; research is published in journal Brain, Behavior and Immunity; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: People living below the poverty line are more likely to have very high levels of C-reactive protein, a marker of inflammation that increases the risk for heart disease and death, a new study has found.     C-reactive protein is produced in response...

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists have developed an ''intelligent'' prosthesis that closely mimics the action of a human foot. Ossur's Proprio Foot uses motion sensors, actuators and software to replace lost muscle function and keep track of where it is in space. Costing $12,000 to $18,000, the device automatically positions itself on stairs or steep ramps -- situations that can be difficult for an amputee. In initial fitting, a ''gait profile'' is created by having the wearer take 15 consecutive steps on level ground. The foot can be worn with or without shoes. FRANK O'CONNELL Adapting to its environment 1. Accelerometers sample the foot's position more than 1,000 times a second. A change in the gait signals that the person may no longer be on a level surface. 2. A motor drive pivots the heel up and down. 3. A sensor in the joint measures the foot's angle, ensuring that the foot is correctly positioned for the next step. Automated advantage Unlike previous artificial feet, the Proprio flexes automatically to the proper position, allowing for more natural walking. Different modes for special situations STAIR MODE Goes into action when the sensors detect two stairs in succession. It rotates the ankle to accommodate steps. RELAX MODE Allows wearer to sit more naturally by lowering toe toward the floor. CHAIR EXIT MODE By tapping the heel in relax mode, wearer flexes ankle forward so the foot can be pulled back. The heel provides shock absorption and allows a more natural walking motion. Its height can be adjusted up to 2 inches via a keypad to accommodate different shoe styles. Developments in prosthetic feet WOODEN LEG 1800's Peg leg for above-theknee amputees. SACH FOOT 1950's Solid ankle, cushion heel. Durable, inexpensive and lightweight. SEATTLE FOOT 1980's First energy-storing foot. Uses a lightweight plastic spring mechanism. FLEX FOOT 1980's First carbon fiber foot. Simulated the spring of a normal foot. COLLEGE PARK FOOT 1990 First to be produced with humanlike joint configuration, allowing ankle motion. (Sources by Ossur; Mark Edwards, Northwestern University Prosthetics-Orthotics Center; University of Manchester Medical School Museum; College Park Industries)

headline.main: An Artificial Foot That Does Everything but Itch

docs.abstract: Prosthetic foot that uses intelligent design to adjust to wearers needs and movements described; drawings (M)
